Approved.

(reordered behavior rules to bring the normal case before the exceptions)

(edited typography, some spelling)

(added example 0, to cover the dead simple cases of state updates ordering before we move to the complex ones)

Pre-solve comments:
- it looks pretty interesting
- it's pretty confusing to try and understand when the inertia changes occur relative to the moving around. *Especially* when it gets to changing direction.
- the whole text feels like it could use an english-native overhaul
- looks like a cool use for zippers, can't wait to start!
There's already a Roller Coaster puzzle in the non-community section (https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/roller-coaster). Please rename yours, or it's going to get VERY confusing around here.
I knew I saw it once ! But I only checked community puzzles...
I made some changes to clear things up, thanks for the early feedback ;)

Note to self about the weird edge cases in the physics:
- moving from horizontal to ascending tracks at low speed results in high speed in the opposite direction
- when stopped, previous direction has an impact on whether to interpret a slope as ascending or descending

Not really mandatory to change anything about them IMHO, the puzzle is fun and interesting as is.

Better.

What I feel is missing is ordering of the following events:
- your inertia changes as a result of the track slope
- you move to the next track element

Example 1: you come to a _ with inertia 1. So your inertia goes to 0. Does the trolley stop in place (since its inertia is now zero) or in the next place (since it came here with positive inertia, it's got to move, right?).

Example 2: you come to a /â€¾ with inertia  10. Do you reach the plateau on the right and stop there (since you arrived with positive inertia), or do you reverse in-place, wait for a moment with inertia 0, then go down?

Both of these sum up as: does the inertia  change occur "on" the track elements, or "between" the track elements?

Solved \o/

(So I got my answers, but the fact remains I had to guess. I suggest you rephrase my examples to integrate them to the statement, it might help others)

That was way easier than I expected :D
